content: hey wg-prioritization!
github enabled on the rust-lang organization a feature in private alpha: issue forms!
they're pretty powerful and we can use them on any repository in the org, including rust-lang/rust
you can see a demo of what we did with them on the docs.rs repo: 1, 2
would y'all be interested in trying them for rust-lang/rust?
They look great!
ok I prepared a doc with all the info you need: https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/rust-lang-issue-forms--BKvbUVhzvjTjmTB369vFlIoFAg-nqAnaBLp1oV5Ojv8W4f6V
let us know what you think and we'll forward the feedback directly to github
(the link to the feature docs is included there)

Is there a simple way to test them, without adding them and creating an issue?

I see, youre writing it right now in the document :+1:
you need to open a PR to the rustc repo with them
(or well, any other repo in the org)
alright. I might give it a try and migrate some of current templates
tbh it's really cool that you can define syntax-highlighted code blocks
and markdown blocks in between fields

That's an interesting tool they're adding, IIUC it is meant as a helpful guidance when opening an issue on a common topic. I'm curious about the difference of creating an issue by using a form with input fields compared to the current option of creating templates with markdown. By skimming through the documentation I think both should translate into the same output (correct me if I'm wrong here).

Perhaps are we interested in a specific additional acton that can be triggered when the form is submitted (ex. I see an option to auto-assign an issue, though this specific example might not be good fit for us)
I see great value in the possiblity for the user to copy and paste a markdown template when opening an issue (example the ICE template), because it's really easy and fast

apiraino said:

Perhaps are we interested in a specific additional acton that can be triggered when the form is submitted (ex. I see an option to auto-assign an issue, though this specific example might not be good fit for us)

it's already possible to have assignees in markdown issues templates!

apiraino said:

That's an interesting tool they're adding, IIUC it is meant as a helpful guidance when opening an issue on a common topic. I'm curious about the difference of creating an issue by using a form with input fields compared to the current option of creating templates with markdown. By skimming the documentation I think both should translate into the same output (correct me if I'm wrong here).

yeah, what I see this does is turning the current practice of having instructions in html comments in the markdown into a proper form, with a few nice things built on top of it (like syntax highlighting for code inputs, checkboxes or dropdowns)
but it should end up with the same output as someone manually creating an issue with a current template
@apiraino I mostly see it as a more intuitive way for users to fill out the existing markdown "forms"
Also it allows making the forms required so people don't just delete them

Joshua Nelson said:

Also it allows making the forms required so people don't just delete them

do people delete markdown templates when opening issues? :-)

anyway, issue forms are an interesting experiment and would probably help when the issue reporter is staring at a blank page and doesnt know well what to write. I'd like to see them deployed and see how people react. Though I hope markdown templates won't go away because (imvho) are more flexible - a form requires the user to fill each field one by one either by copy and paste or manual typing (which I assume very few people do).
A nice addition would be an option to turn the form back to an editable template and A/B test how much would people click that option
(the "preview" view when opening an issue helps checking if my formatting is correct)

do people delete markdown templates when opening issues? :-)

Occasionally yes, they just won't add the build link for build failure issues.
